But in June, the Supreme Court green-lit such penalties, prompting Gov. Gavin Newsom to order California city officials to “move urgently” to clear illegal encampments around the state.
According to Mayor London Breed, the intention is to clean up sidewalks and force unhoused people into the city’s labyrinthine network of shelter and supportive housing programs.
A federal survey released in May counted more than 8,000 unhoused people in the city, which has fewer than 4,000 shelter beds to offer.

Joey O’Brien, 46, tried to explain to police officers that he was camping on the sidewalk in Hunters Point while investigating a homicide that occurred while he was in jail.
Source Justification: camping on the sidewalk in Hunters Point while investigating a homicide that occurred while he was in jail

Sourced Statements: After listening for about two minutes, an officer told him that he was being detained for illegal lodging, then put O’Brien in cuffs and led him to a patrol vehicle away from his camp.
“I don’t understand,” O’Brien kept repeating.
More than anything, however, he begged for officers to bring over his two neat backpacks, which had his best clothes, documents, and “bits of silver.”
“The other stuff is under all that over there,” the officer said with a shrug. “You’re going to have to pick it up later.”

as a recent batch of public records secured by City Hall watchdog Hazel Williams shows, Public Works has bagged medications, wheelchairs, and even a mobility walker from unhoused people, taking them to the city’s storage facility on Cesar Chavez St.
Many unhoused people, including Robinson, say it can be challenging to identify and retrieve their belongings at the facility.
Source Justification: When they succeed, they often find important pieces missing from their stash — a problem that has persisted over years of sweeps.
